(1 comment)

This seems like a good idea, but I have some implementation questions. Also, what exactly is different between the "Google" and the "standard" PID loop algorithm?

I have some algorithmic changes I also want to make, however, I don't want to break existing PID loop tunings by changing any default computational behavior. I want to make this a selectable feature, though, perhaps with a flag. I like your idea of having a different name for it, however.

I had written up a quick summary on Github, which I'll paste below.  In a nutshell, the Google algorithm is a pseudo-PI[D] controller chained with another PI controller, which from a control theory perspective isn't something we want to ship (potential for instability).  The algorithm Raptor added is standard PID, without the unwanted chained PI controller tacked on.

Thank you for not breaking our tuning. :)  The algorithm here (standard PID) is already used on Kestrel (Zephyr RTOS), and we already have the tuned coefficients for our platforms as a result.

"The existing Google EC algorithm is not workable for the Raptor and SIE (patches coming in the future) platforms, as it is not a standard PID controller. Raptor uses standard PID controllers in its firmware, for example in its Kestrel BMC products, as after extensive testing we have found that our fan control hardware is best controlled (i.e. minimum overshoot and hunting) via a standard PID algorithm.

In this patch, the algorithm type used defaults to the Google algorithm, but can be changed in the JSON configuration file.

This is the first set of patches in a series that aims to add full support for the Raptor Computing Systems POWER9 platforms to OpenBMC."

There is a reason the thermal PID loops run at 1.0 seconds and the fan PID loops run at 0.1 seconds by default. This should not be changed without a good reason.

The thermal loops often have to process many more sensors than the fan loops do, putting more load on the system. Also, thermal sensors tend to change slower than fan sensors. So, it is intentional for the main loop to only process the thermal PID only 1 out of each 10 iterations, while processing the fan PID every iteration.

In testing, this speed was insufficient to get proper control of the fans on two of our platforms, with oscillation / hunting behavior observed.  If I were to make this a tunable would that be acceptable?
Done

Is there a difference between "fan" and "simplefan", other than selection of the PID loop algorithm? If not, it might make for a cleaner design to just add another field, perhaps "Algorithm", that can be set to values like "google" or "standard".
Yes, the default "fan" controller adds a second unwanted PI controller into the control loop.

Ah, so the PID loop algorithm does not change? In this case, instead of calling it "simplefan", perhaps call it "single" to represent the fact that it is just a single PID loop doing the work of both a thermal and a fan PID loop.
This code looks copied, but differs. Among other things, addPidFailSafePercent() is not done. Is this intentional?
Could be an inadvertent difference due to the age of the original patches.  I'll take a closer look.
Done

Instead of doing an indentation of everything that follows, it might be simpler here to test for the opposite condition, and if true, take an early return here. That will avoid having to change the entire rest of the function.
If that's acceptable from a style perspective, I'm happy to do so.
Done
PID as a constant is too generic, as it is already a PIDControlType. To be common with your other code, I suggest SIMPLE or STANDARD.
Will fix.
Done

I am curious. What about this function is different from the way the PID algorithm used to be computed previously?

Also, it looks like a lot of cut-and-paste code. I would prefer only the different parts be changed, instead of copying the entire file.

The existing controller is not a true PID, if you trace the mathematics of it it's some kind of combination stepwise and PI controller.  This was a significant source of heartburn during development, as it simply wouldn't tune on our hardware platforms.

I'd prefer a separate file simply to keep the mathematics clean vs. a bunch of if statements.  Is that OK?
Hmm...what do you mean "it's some kind of combination stepwise and PI controller"? AFAIK, if there doesn't have any stepwise setting in json, it's just like a PID controller.

What exactly is changed here, between the original pid.cpp file, and this copy of it? The code looks about 99% the same to me, except for some differences in line spacing.

I would rather it remain the same file, unless the PID algorithm is being completely rewritten, which does not look to be the case here. If only a few lines are being changed, use an if/else block to isolate the differences. Please do not cut-and-paste the entire file.

Also, the pid.cpp and stepwise.cpp are two different algorithms. They are already cleanly isolated. The PID controller and stepwise controller are separate subclasses. See the controller.hpp file for the common ancestor. A properly configured system should not have any "combination stepwise and PI controller". I am not sure where this misunderstanding came from.

How does a simple fan controller differ from the default fan controller? It looks to be much the same code. I would prefer to avoid massive cut-and-paste code duplication here. Perhaps we can only override what actually changes, instead of having to cut-and-paste the entire class.
The simple fan controller doesn't add the unwanted second PI controller in the control loop.  Interestingly, this should also fix issue #32 over on Github.
OK. See my other comment in simplefancontroller.hpp for my reasoning about that. I think it's good to fix issue #32, but I honestly don't think this technique is the best way to fix it.

Does it output RPM values, or does it output PWM values? Usually, the thermal PID loop outputs the desired RPM values, then the fan PID loop converts RPM to PWM and outputs the actual PWM values to the hardware.

Some systems have a smart fan controller, in which RPM drives the fans, not PWM. In this case, the thermal PID loop outputs RPM, and no further processing is necessary, as the fan hardware can receive the desired RPM directly. PWM is not used at all.

Also, in another case, the RPM is not cared about at all by the user, and the thermal PID loop is tuned to output the desired PWM percentage. RPM is not used at all.

In both of these cases, usually a dummy PID loop that's 1:1 is used, to just copy the setpoint to the output, and ignore the input.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/issues/32
The last case is what we're looking for.  I don't see why we need the added complexity and computational overhead of the dummy PI loop?

One thing I'm interested. The first thermal controller output actually can be RPM or PWM according parameter setting, and we can setting second loop parameters that only have FFGain to output to fan directly. Why need add a new controller to remove second PID loop? Does it make a large delay in your system?

Agree with Harvey here. It would be good to refactor to make only a single PID loop necessary. The code right now assumes a pipeline of a thermal PID loop feeding into a fan PID loop, hence the need for two PID loops. This should be refactored, so that a single PID loop is all that is necessary. I agree with that. However, I do not think that adding an additional duplicate PID controller class is the best way to do it. It adds a lot of duplicated cut-and-paste code. The refactoring should take place at the glue where the thermal PID controller and fan PID controller come together, instead of by creating a third PID controller.
Hmm. It seems last_error got duplicated here? Lines 58 and 60
Merge issue during rebase.  I'll fix this up.
Done

This reminds me. What's the difference between a "Google" PID loop, and a "standard" PID loop? Do they provide different output results? If so, then we need to have a test case for each of these.

The test case must be able to catch the condition in which the user erroneously specifies a Google loop instead of a standard loop, and also vice versa.
Difference was explained above, I'll need to look into the test cases for it.
The existing test cases are unaffected by this.  In fact I don't really see anything (on quick glance) that's checking PID output, so I think we're OK with the existing test cases?

The PID loop input and output are both tested. Take a look at "outputProc" in the test directory, you will see it used in several places. It's true that outputProc is often the final statement of the test case, so it may look like the output is discarded at first glance, but the result is actually tested retroactively by the EXPECT_CALL statement just above it.
Wow, good catch, this was forgotten about.
Thanks for explanations. There are still some serious reservations about the overall design of this feature, though.

It looks like sometime after the standard PID feature was implemented back in 2022 the Google PID loop was fixed (e.g. via hash 0e8fc398), and may finally be useable in terms of the actual mathematics.

That said, the timestep issues and chained PID loops are a hard blocker, they are known to cause instability on multiple platforms for at least two vendors (one of these vendors is now carrying a complete custom controller internally as a result of the earlier issues).

Are you open to a patch set that allows the unwanted second PID to be removed (along with its latency), and that would allow the tick rate to be increased to 100ms?  If so, I can put a new patch series together.
The pidTimestep can not be passed in here, as it is a zone-wide parameter, not a per-PID-loop parameter. See commentary below.

The "ts" parameter should probably be removed completely here. Unfortunately, the way the code is written now, we can not vary the timing as a per-PID-loop parameter. It needs to be instead a zone-wide parameter. Each zone has its own main loop. The fan PID loops are ran as a ratio of the thermal PID loops. The individual PID loops are not individually timed. Take a look at the pidControlLoop() function.

Why need this? We already have "CycleIntervalTimeMS" and "UpdateThermalsTimeMS" this two settings by zone that can change the fan and thermal pid loop timing.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/57660
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/58797
Hmm, both sides of the if/else statement have the same code in them? It does not make sense to have this be an if/else statement, if both sides do the exact same thing.
This moving seems redundant? The code are the same.
Agreed. It looks like a simple error made during rebasing to the latest upstream changes. Should be easy to fix, by moving it back to the original location, if there is no reason to change it.
What is this semicolon doing here?
